prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information
Review of Duties and Acknowledgment by Employee

para.paratext: With respect to the actual execution of an employment agreement, the employer should ensure that the employee clearly understands what he or she is signing. The employer should review the contract with the employee on a paragraph by paragraph basis and should specifically address each clause relating to the use of confidential information. The employee should be given the opportunity to read and understand each of the terms of the agreement. Finally, the employee should be given reasonable time to consider the terms of the agreement and to obtain appropriate legal advice. In most cases, the courts will be sympathetic to an employee where it appears that the employee was under any duress or pressure to sign an agreement.

Employers should consider the impact on the employee of each clause relating to the use of confidential information. This is particularly true of non-competition clauses. For example, where an employee will not be able to work in a certain geographic area, industry or business, and will be unable to find alternative employment or even earn a living, the employer should consider narrowing the clause. Most clauses should be worded to cover a defined territory and to prevent the employee from attacking specific corporate opportunities or customer connections as a result of information obtained during the employment relationship.

Where possible, standard form contracts should be avoided. Every employment contract should be adjusted to reflect the particular terms of the individual employment relationship. At the very least, the basic terms, including the employee's name, position, remuneration, duties, etc., should be specifically set forth as part of the agreement, as opposed to merely being filled in on a pre-printed contract. In addition, the terms of the agreement must be consistent with all corporate policies. A copy of the contract and relevant company policies should be provided to the employee.

Employees should sign an agreement before starting employment in order to avoid a claim for constructive dismissal. Similarly, where an employee receives a promotion, the employee should sign any new agreement prior to the change actually occurring.
